titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, South Africa UPDATE Series Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, South Africa UPDATE Series Files FA1548

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 17:54:29 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, South Africa UPDATE Series Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection is comprised of files pertaining to the preparation, production, and promotion of the South Africa UPDATE Series. The Ford Foundation initiated the UPDATE Series project in order to update the South Africa: Time Running Out report (SATRO) that was published in 1981 by the Study Commission on U.S. Policy Towards Southern Africa. The series consists of five monographs. Each book focuses on a particular theme regarding political developments in South Africa during the 1980s. Subjects covered in the series include international relations between South Africa and the United States, politics in the region of Southern Africa, political activism of Black South Africans; reforms made to the Apartheid system, and the state of civil rights in South Africa.

Two of the five series in the collection contain the bulk of the collection's contents. They are Series 1. Chronological files and Series 4. Manuscripts and working files. The chronological files consist of correspondence, memos, drafts, invoices, purchase orders, expense reports, budget information, petty cash vouchers, agreements, and consultant requests. They document the work of the UPDATE Series Editor John de St. Jorre, Associate Editor Elinor Bowles, and Editorial Board in reaching out to prospective authors and readers of monographs, revising manuscripts, preparing the books' design, publishing and disseminating the books, and promoting the series. The manuscripts and working files series contains complete drafts of the writings included in several of the South Africa UPDATE monographs as well as readers' comments on the drafts, correspondence between the series' editors and the different authors, and supplementary materials to the writings. Some copies of the drafts have been saved to floppy disks.

The third and fourth series in the collection are chiefly comprised of the UPDATE Series editors' correspondence with monograph authors, research assistants, and monograph testimonial writers. Copies of monograph testimonials are also included in Series 3.

Lastly, the editorial files in Series 5 contain articles, newspaper clippings, reports, and publications that the series' editors more than likely collected for background information on the subjects discussed in the South Africa UPDATE books.

The collection contains materials from two different sets of records transferred to the RAC. The first set of material processed into the collection originated from a group of boxes containing Ford Foundation program strategy records. The documents' original storage containers and content indicated that the documents all concerned the South Africa UPDATE Series, so they were therefore processed as a discrete collection. They comprise Series 1-3 in the collection.

Another set of material related to the South Africa UPDATE Series was discovered at a later time within a group of boxes containing Ford Foundation publications. These records were added to the collection as Series 4 and 5.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as part of two different accessions: Accession 2019:046 Ford Foundation records, Program Strategy records and Accession 2019:051, Ford Foundation records, Publications.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is comprised of five series. Records in the first three series originated from Accession 2019:046, Ford Foundation records, Program Strategy records, and records in the last two series originated from Accession 2019:051, Ford Foundation records, Publications.
Files in Series 1 were arranged in order to restore the intended chronological organization.
Series 2. Authors and research assistants' correspondence, 1990-1992

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation launched the South Africa UPDATE Series project in the late 1980s in order to update the South Africa: Time Running Out report (SATRO). The Study Commission on U.S. Policy Towards Southern Africa published the SATRO report in 1981. The Commission was funded by the Rockefeller Foundation and chaired by Ford Foundation President Franklin Thomas.

The UPDATE Series Editorial Board sought to update the SATRO report with a series of monographs that discussed recent political developments in South Africa. The Editorial Board emerged in part from the Ford Foundation's Southern Africa Study Group. Foundation staff members Franklin Thomas, Lynn Walker, and Gary Sick sat on the Board. John de St. Jorre served as Editor, Elinor Bowles served as Associate Editor, and Milfred Fierce served as Consulting Editor.

Monographs in the series concern topics like international relations between South Africa and the United States, politics in the region of Southern Africa, political activism of black South Africans; reforms made to the Apartheid system, and the state of civil rights in South Africa.
The five South Africa UPDATE monographs are titled:
The United States and South Africa: The Reagan Years
All, Here, and Now: Black Politics in South Africa in the 1980s
Adapt or Die: The End of White Politics in South Africa
Changing Fortunes: War, Diplomacy, and Economics in Southern Africa
The Last Years of Apartheid: Civil Liberties in South Africa

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The first group of materials processed into the Ford Foundation records, South Africa UPDATE Series Files collection originated from a set of Ford Foundation program strategy records transferred to the RAC (Accession 2019:046). Sequential box numbers on the original containers and analysis of the containers' contents suggested that the documents all related to the South Africa UPDATE Series. It was therefore decided to process the records as a discrete collection.

Another group of materials related to the South Africa UPDATE Series was discovered in a set of Ford Foundation publications transferred to the RAC (Accession 2019:051). These records were processed into the collection at a later date.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the chronological files that document the preparation, production, and promotion of the South Africa UPDATE Series. Correspondence, memos, drafts, invoices, purchases orders, expense reports, budget information, petty cash vouchers, agreements, and consultant requests document the work of the UPDATE Series Editor John de St Jorre, Associate Editor Elinor Bowles, and Editorial Board in hiring prospective monograph authors and readers, revising manuscripts, preparing the books' design, contracting organizations to co-publish and disseminate the books, and promoting the series. The editors and Editorial Board sought to promote the series through regional meetings, professional meetings, complimentary copies of monographs, monograph authors' appearances, and advertisements in publications. Meetings of the Editorial Board are also documented within the series.

physdesc.extent: About half LTR size Hollinger box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains correspondence between the South Africa UPDATE Series editors, Elinor Bowles and John de St. Jorre, and the series' different authors and research assistants. Correspondence generally regards the preparation and revisions of manuscripts, preparation of other components of the books such as footnotes and bibliographies, the distribution of authors' copies of published books, payments to authors, and promotion of the books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains correspondence between the South Africa UPDATE Series editors, Elinor Bowles and John de St. Jorre, and authors of the testimonials for the different books in the series as well as copies of the published testimonials. Correspondence documents the editors reaching out to the writers to see if they would be interested in writing a testimonial as well as the editors thanking the writers for their services.

physdesc.extent: 6 LTR size and 2.5 LGL size Hollinger boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the manuscripts and workings files that South Africa UPDATE Series editors Elinor Bowles and John de St. Jorre created in order to document the drafting and revising of the series' monographs. The manuscripts in the series are different drafts of writings used in several of the South Africa UPDATE books. Looking at these drafts, researchers can see how the writings changed over time through the process of editing and revising done by the editors and authors. The other files in the series contain correspondence between the editors and authors discussing revisions and improvements to the drafts, readers' comments on the drafts, and supplemental materials such as author biographies and footnotes.
The records' creators used abbreviated terms to refer to the titles of the different monographs in the series. These abbreviations are:
Black Politics (All, Here, and Now: Black Politics in South Africa in the 1980s)
Region (Changing Fortunes: War, Diplomacy, and Economics in Southern Africa)
White Politics (Adapt or Die: The End of White Politics in South Africa)

The series does not contain any files specifically created to house documents for the other two South Africa UPDATE books, The United States and South Africa: The Reagan Years and The Last Years of Apartheid: Civil Liberties in South Africa. However, one of the White Politics files does include some material related to The United States and South Africa: The Reagan Years book.
Future transfers of records to the RAC from the Ford Foundation may add more of this material to the collection.

did.unittitle: White Politics - Lisa and Marius: A Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains a set of materials that the records' creators referred to as editorial files. These editorial files consist of articles, newspaper clippings, reports, and publications that discuss political developments and news in South Africa during the 1980s. One of the files in the series includes a piece of John de St. Jorre's correspondence that suggests that these types of materials were submitted to the South Africa UPDATE Series' editors as background information on the subjects discussed within the series' monographs.

The writings collected within the editorial files concern topics such as South African international relations, political activism and resistance to Apartheid by South African blacks, economic advancement of some South African blacks and a black middle-class, anti-Apartheid organizations like the African National Congress (ANC) and the United Democratic Front (UDF), anti-Apartheid leaders like Nelson Mandela, Winnie Mandela, Desmond Tutu, Oliver Tambo, and Mangosuthu Buthelezi, political divisions between different anti-Apartheid groups and the call for black unity made by some anti-Apartheid leaders, suspected links between anti-Apartheid groups and communism, proposed government reforms, and advancements toward negotiations to end Apartheid.
